poem:
Title: "In the Halls of Justice"

Beneath London's stern sky,
Nine-thirty — Assange, about to know his fate.
"This is it," breathes his love, ripe with antipathy.
Assange, Heart of WikiLeaks, a fervent fighter.
Decision clasped in robed hands - 
years whittled to this: a moment balanced,
Awash in the crisp morning air,
A verdict will tremble or stand firm.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Julian Assange extradition appeal: what you need to know before the UK high court’s ruling Julian Assange will learn whether he can fight to stop his extradition to the United States at 9.30pm AEDT (10.30am UK time) on Tuesday when two senior judges of London’s high court hand down their ruling. “This is it,” his wife, Stella Assange, said in a post to X. “DECISION TOMORROW.” The WikiLeaks founder has since 2019 battled extradition from". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
